results.title: The Lindsay Kemp Circus
results.creator_credit: Contemporary Films, Douglas Eadie and Oscar Marzaroli
results.brief_description: Presents Lindsay Kemp, the most accomplished mime artist to emerge from Britain, his extraordinary co-star Orlando and their troupe. The film reflects the “lush decadence” of their work - Kemp performing the ultimate tatty striptease and Orlando singing “I Must Have A Man”.

results.title: The Lin family shop = Linjia puzi [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Peking Film Studio, Shih Ping, Li Kan and Shui Hua
results.brief_description: At the centre of the story is a small-time merchant’s struggle for financial survival in a provincial town in the early 1930s. The novel by Yuan Chu and Mao Tun from which it was adapted came out of the May 4th Movement and has been described as ‘a lament for the patriotic bourgeoisie suffering from economic hardship of foreign competition’. Literature from this politically radical and western influenced movement became the subject of popularisation on the screen in the 1950s (see also Early Spring). Most pre-1949 filmmakers had been part of this cultural strain (see Street Angel). ‘The Lin Family Shop’ is regarded as the best of such fifties adaptations. The period is carefully evoked but the filmmakers were aware of the need to prevent audience identification with the shopkeeper who remains an understandable (if hardly sympathetic) figure. A narrator at the end provides the ‘right perspective’. Cast includes Wei Wei, Hsieh Tien, Han Tao. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: The Lilith summer
results.brief_description: Based on a novel by Hadley Irwin. It tells the story of an unlikely friendship between an 11 year old girl and a 77 year old woman which develops into mutual acceptance and understanding.

results.title: The Lightship
results.creator_credit: CBS Productions, Bill Benenson Productions, Bill Beneson, Moritz Borman and Jerzy Skolimowski
results.brief_description: Based on an allegorical novella by Siegfried Lenz, this moody, carefully crafted suspense by Polish director Jerzy Skolimowski (Moonlighting, The Shout) is set in 1955 aboard an isolated U.S. Coast Guard lightship anchored in dangerous waters off the coast of Norfolk, Virginia. The pacifist captain (Klaus Maria Brandauer), is a German-American who is haunted by an event in his naval past when he was indirectly responsible for the deaths at sea of some sailors during WWII. When he rescues a drifting speedboat from an impending storm, he is confronted by a trio of modern day pirates led by the menacing, psychotic Caspary (played in a no-holds-barred performance by Robert Duvall), on their way to pick up illicit cargo. From the moment they board the lightship the thugs attempt to take control, resulting in a violent struggle between good and evil. With the atmosphere becoming increasingly tense and hostile, conflicts arise amongst the crew as their misguided attempts at heroism end tragically. Cast also includes Tom Bower, Robert Costanzo, and Michael Lyndon.

results.title: The Lighthouse keeper
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, R. Maslyn Williams and Lionel Trainor
results.brief_description: A fascinating study of a lighthouse-keeper and his family, who tend one of the vital beacons in the storm-tossed waters south of Tasmania - on Maatsuyker Island. The film is outstanding for its treatment of the duties of the lighthouse-keeper, whose life is governed entirely by the light. Photography by Geoffrey Powell; music by Robert W. Hughes.

results.title: The Lighthouse
results.brief_description: The opening sequences of this film remind us that the British Isles lie in one of the storm belts of the world, where fog is also a shipping hazzard; animation shows the large number of lighthouses all round British shores. Their position is shown in relation to shipping lanes, and the traffic in these lanes, and in relation to the chief ports. The life of the lighthouse keeper, and his duties, are also dealt with in detail.

results.title: The Light fantastick
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Wolf Koenig, Rupert Glover and Michel Patenaude
results.brief_description: A detailed retrospective of the animation film at the National Film Board of Canada, of the techniques employed, and of the men and women who used and sometimes invented them. Documentary footage explains the techniques, and clips from NFB films illustrate the often spectacular results. Topics include Norman McLaren, hand-drawn-on-film and pixillation techniques, the “sing-along” animated songs of the 1940s, Alexandre Alexeieff’s pinscreen, and Evelyn Lambart’s fairytale improvisations. (Awards: New York; San Francisco; Salerno.)

results.title: The Light
results.brief_description:
Brian Doyle’s award-winning videos, installations and photos have been shown in galleries and film festivals throughout America and Europe. His latest body of work Yestermorrow (2000), Current (2001) and The Light
(2003) use the pretext of a developing storm to expose the ephemeral forces at play around us. Doyle documents phenomena that routinely affect our lives, uncovering alternate layers of reality below the surface of our recognition. Doyle’s collision of nature and culture invest everyday occurrences and familiar spaces with an otherworldly aura.

Doyle filmed across the United States in New York, Florida and Nevada, but The Light ultimately describes a non-place. Journeying from the countryside to urban construction grounds and the illumination of New York, light becomes a powerful metaphor for humanity’s struggle, through technology and determination,
to ‘pierce the night and see through the darkness’.

Beginning with the most simple of structures, a glowing street lamp, The Light gracefully charts a procession of increasingly complex illuminations. The film slowly builds toward the memorial light columns of the World Trade Center, which are shown not in direct conjunction with 9/11 but as the formal and abstracted transcendence of pure light.

(SW 30.03.05)
